helpdesk_ticket.description_html:
Dear PharmEasy Support Team,

I am writing regarding my order #654388715803353088, for which a complaint has already been raised (Complaint No: 22256320).

The order has been delayed for a long time, and this delay is causing serious concern as the medicines are required urgently for my mother, who is undergoing treatment for a heart-related disease. This is critical medication, and any further delay can risk her health.

I request you to please look into this matter on priority and ensure the order is delivered at the earliest. Kindly provide a clear update on the status and expected delivery time.

Looking forward to your prompt response.

Thank you,
Vikas Shukla
pH:- 8080310935/8898410935

helpdesk_ticket.description:
Dear Pharmeasy Customer Support Team,

I am writing to request a *return and refund* for my recent purchase
of *Sunsilk
Lusciously Thick & Long Shampoo (1 Ltr)*.

Upon receiving the product, I noticed the following discrepancies:

   1.

   *MRP Difference*
   -

      Invoice MRP: *₹1370/-*
      -

      Actual Product MRP received: *₹1079/-*
      2.

   *Expiry Date Mismatch*
   -

      Invoice expiry: *10/28*
      -

      Product expiry received: *06/26* (near expiry)
      3.

   At the time of placing the order, *there was no information shown that
   the item was non-returnable*.

Since the product received does not match the invoice details and is near
expiry, I request you to kindly *accept the return and issue a full refund*.

I have attached the *invoice copy and product pictures* for your reference.


Regards,
Sagar Patel
97260 66085

--

helpdesk_ticket.subject: Request for Return & Refund – Wrong MRP and Near-Expiry Product Received
helpdesk_ticket.description_html:
Dear Pharmeasy Customer Support Team,

I am writing to request a return and refund for my recent purchase of Sunsilk Lusciously Thick & Long Shampoo (1 Ltr).
Upon receiving the product, I noticed the following discrepancies:
  1. MRP Difference
    • Invoice MRP: ₹1370/-
    • Actual Product MRP received: ₹1079/-
  2. Expiry Date Mismatch
    • Invoice expiry: 10/28
    • Product expiry received: 06/26 (near expiry)
  3. At the time of placing the order, there was no information shown that the item was non-returnable.
Since the product received does not match the invoice details and is near expiry, I request you to kindly accept the return and issue a full refund.
I have attached the invoice copy and product pictures for your reference.

Regards,
Sagar Patel
97260 66085

You are requested to advise the sender, of your receipt of this email by return e-mail. The Company and its affiliates rule out any and every liability resulting from this or any other electronic transmission.

notes.body: Hello Sagar,     Greetings from PharmEasy!     This email is with regards to your order #654570248395014144-76656,  as checked, your concern was highlighted for the missing item. We apologize for any inconvenience caused to you with your order.     As per update received from our team, please be informed that an issue was raised for the missing SUNSILK LUSCIOUSLY THICK & LONG SHAMPOO 1 LTR . As checked, the issue is verified and a refund of Rs. 133.86 /- has been credited  to your PharmEasy wallet on 10 December 2025.      We are marking the ticket as resolved. We are marking the ticket as resolved. If you have any queries, please feel free to get back to us.

notes.body:
Merged from ticket 22285217  
      Subject: URGENT: Order Delayed / Stuck in Transit - Order ID: PKFLKZP0361751  
      Description:  
 Dear PharmEasy Support Team, 
 ​I am writing to report a serious delay with my order #PKFLKZP0361751. 
 ​According to the tracking details, this package was picked up on December 7th, but the tracking shows it has been stuck in Gurugram (Motherhub_JKS) with no movement for over a week. The current status on Shiprocket says "Arriving Late" due to network delays. 
 ​I urgently need this order delivered before December 19th, 2025.
 
 ​Please coordinate with your logistics partner (Shiprocket/Ekart) immediately to fast-track this shipment to my location in Sahjanwa. If it cannot be delivered by the 18th, please let me know immediately so I can make alternative arrangements. 
 ​Order Details:
 
 
 ​PharmEasy Order ID: PKFLKZP0361751 
 ​Courier Tracking ID: BSRC0257049767 
 ​Courier Partner: Shiprocket / Ekart Logistics 
 
 ​I have attached screenshots of the tracking status showing the delay. 
 ​Please treat this as a priority.

Merged from ticket 22285217

Subject: URGENT: Order Delayed / Stuck in Transit - Order ID: PKFLKZP0361751

Description:
Dear PharmEasy Support Team,
​I am writing to report a serious delay with my order #PKFLKZP0361751.
​According to the tracking details, this package was picked up on December 7th, but the tracking shows it has been stuck in Gurugram (Motherhub_JKS) with no movement for over a week. The current status on Shiprocket says "Arriving Late" due to network delays.
​I urgently need this order delivered before December 19th, 2025.
​Please coordinate with your logistics partner (Shiprocket/Ekart) immediately to fast-track this shipment to my location in Sahjanwa. If it cannot be delivered by the 18th, please let me know immediately so I can make alternative arrangements.
​Order Details:
  • ​PharmEasy Order ID: PKFLKZP0361751
  • ​Courier Tracking ID: BSRC0257049767
  • ​Courier Partner: Shiprocket / Ekart Logistics
​I have attached screenshots of the tracking status showing the delay.
​Please treat this as a priority.

notes.body_html:
Hello Mohd Azam,

Greetings from PharmEasy!
 
This email is with reference to the concern raised for order #654756835343945728-32144. 
 
We can see that your order was canceled on 16 December 2025. Due to some unforeseen circumstances and operational issues at logistic end, the order was not delivered to you by the expected date of delivery. We apologize for the inconvenience caused to you with your order.

We have shared the required feedback with the delivery partner and we will make sure that such instances are not repeated in the future.
 
We would request you to place a new order and we will ensure the order is delivered to you on priority.
 
Be rest assured as we have jotted down the details of your experience and PharmEasy will ensure all appropriate actions are taken to prevent similar situations from happening in the future. Looking forward to delighting you soon.
 
If you have any queries, please feel free to get back to us.
 
For any further assistance, please reopen this ticket or reach out to us through our support channels, in the App or website, listed in the 'Need Help' section.
 
Thank you for choosing PharmEasy. Have a great day ahead!
 
Regards,
PharmEasy

helpdesk_ticket.description:
Respected sir

I ordered few medicine from your app on 26 November and I received the
parcel on 2nd December on COD. When I opened the parcel and checked all the
items I found one of Suncross Aqualotion spf 50 was missing from its box
and there was only empty box for that piece. Other items were intact.
Immediately I registered my complaint with your customer care but after
waiting for five days I found that they didn't even registered my
complaint. I made another complaint, but no refund, they said they created
the pickup for the empty box but the courier boy refused to take empty box
citing that in their system it's showing to pick the product and they
cannot pick the empty box otherwise they have to bear the cost. I made
another complaint at customer care , they assured me to pick up as soon as
possible but courier boy refused to pickup again citing the same reason.

Now could you please tell me what to do with them. I am thinking of making
complaint at National consumer forum if it's not resolved because I am fed
up of these type of irresponsible behaviour on the part of your customer
care team.

Therefore I request you to resolve this issue as soon as possible and
provide me my refund.

Thank you
Richa Agarwal
8876755318

--

helpdesk_ticket.subject: Not refunding of money for the missing item from the received parcel
helpdesk_ticket.description_html:
Respected sir

I ordered few medicine from your app on 26 November and I received the parcel on 2nd December on COD. When I opened the parcel and checked all the items I found one of Suncross Aqualotion spf 50 was missing from its box and there was only empty box for that piece. Other items were intact. Immediately I registered my complaint with your customer care but after waiting for five days I found that they didn't even registered my complaint. I made another complaint, but no refund, they said they created the pickup for the empty box but the courier boy refused to take empty box citing that in their system it's showing to pick the product and they cannot pick the empty box otherwise they have to bear the cost. I made another complaint at customer care , they assured me to pick up as soon as possible but courier boy refused to pickup again citing the same reason.

Now could you please tell me what to do with them. I am thinking of making complaint at National consumer forum if it's not resolved because I am fed up of these type of irresponsible behaviour on the part of your customer care team. 

Therefore I request you to resolve this issue as soon as possible and provide me my refund.

Thank you 
Richa Agarwal 
8876755318

helpdesk_ticket.description:
*To:* PharmEasy Legal Team
*CC:* CEO, Axelia Solutions Pvt. Ltd (Platform Operator)
*CC:* CEO, Threpsi Solutions Pvt. Ltd (Brand Owner)



*1. Subject*

*Repeated illegal delivery of wrong diabetic medicines (THIRD TIME), health
endangerment, false delivery claims, refusal to replace/refund, and
non-payment of compensation. Final notice before filing consumer case &
FIR.*



*2. Consolidated Incident Timeline (All Violations)*

*A. FIRST INCIDENT – June 2025*

·       Correct medicine ordered: *Dianorm M OD 1000 mg*

·       Wrong medicine delivered: *Dianorm M OD 500 mg*

·       Health harm caused: *Blood sugar spike to 400 mg/dL*

·       Replacement/refund delayed for *10+ days* despite medical emergency

·       Compensation pending since *24-Jun-2025 (68+ days at that time, now
160+ days)*

·       False “failed delivery” claim on *11-Aug-2025*

·       No accountability, no medical damage compensation



*B. SECOND INCIDENT – 01 Aug 2025*

·       Repeated delivery error (again wrong dosage)

·       Still no corrective action

·       No compensation

·       No accountability

·       Continues to remain unresolved



*C. THIRD INCIDENT – 07–08 Dec 2025 (NEW – REPEAT OFFENCE)*

*Order ID:* *656531285027880960*
*Order Date:* 07-Dec-2025
*Expected medicine:* *Dianorm M OD 1000 mg – 9 strips*
*Delivered instead:* *Dianorm M OD 500 mg*
*Delivery Timestamp:* 08-Dec-2025 @ 16:25 hrs

This is now the *third instance of supplying the wrong diabetic medicine*,
after:

1.    Severe health harm already caused earlier

2.    Prior legal notice

3.    Multiple escalations

4.    Previous wrong 500 mg strips still not taken back

5.    No refund, no replacement, no compensation

This establishes:

·       *Gross negligence*

·       *Willful disregard of patient safety*

·       *Systemic failure in PharmEasy supply chain*

·       *Criminal negligence* (Sec 338 IPC)

·       *Breach of Drugs & Cosmetics Act* (Sec 18(a))

·       *Unfair trade practice* (CPA Sec 2(9))

·       *Deficiency in service* (CPA Sec 2(1)(o))

·       *Endangering a medically vulnerable consumer*



*3. PharmEasy’s Responses Show Continued Evasion*

Your email dated *02-Sep-2025* again discussed:

·       ₹1,200 wallet refund

·       ₹995 refund

·       ₹2,000 refund request; thereafter, no response.

*None* of these have any relevance to the:

·       *Health damage caused*

·       *Repeated wrong delivery*

·       *Criminal violations*

·       *Pending compensation* for June, August, and now December violations

·       *Non-collection of wrong medicines*

·       *Delay of 160+ days in grievance resolution*

Your repeated template emails prove *willful evasion* of legal
responsibility.



*4. Legal Violations (Complete List)*

*A. Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940*

·       *Section 18(a)* – Supplying incorrect dosage of a prescription drug
(three times).

*B. Consumer Protection Act, 2019*

·       *Section 2(1)(o)* – Deficiency in service

·       *Section 2(9)(ii)* – Unfair trade practice

·       *Section 14(1)(d)* – Mandatory compensation for harm

*C. IPC (Indian Penal Code)*

·       *Sec 338* – Grievous hurt by negligence

·       *Sec 191* – False statements / perjury (“failed delivery” claim)

*D. E-Commerce Rules, 2020*

·       *Rule 5(2)* – Failure to ensure accurate delivery

·       *Rule 5(3)* – Failure to redress grievances



*5. My Demands (FINAL & NON-NEGOTIABLE)*

*1. Compensation for Damages: ₹6,50,000 (*(Breakdown: ₹4L health damages +
₹2L mental agony + ₹50K legal costs)

For:

·       Severe spikes in blood sugar

·       Medical risk & treatment

·       Mental agony

·       Time loss

·       Legal costs

·       160+ days of unresolved grievance

*2. Immediate Delivery of Correct Medicine*

·       *5 strips* pending from earlier orders

·       *9 strips* from 07-Dec-2025 order

·       Return pickup of *all wrongly delivered 500 mg strips* (multiple
months pending)

*3. CEO-Signed Written Acknowledgement of Error*

As repeated drug dosage errors qualify as *life-threatening negligence*.



*6. Final Legal Action (If Not Resolved Within 12 Hours)*

I will be proceeding with:

*A. E-Daakhil Consumer Court Filing*

·       Claim amount: *₹10,00,000*

·       Injunction request to restrict PharmEasy’s prescription medicine
deliveries

*B. Police FIR*

·       *Sec 338 IPC*

·       *Sec 27 Drugs & Cosmetics Act*

*C. DCGI Complaint*

·       Request for investigation & license action

*D. Public Disclosure*

·       Media submission

·       Social media (#PharmEasyEndangersLives #PharmEasyGivesWrongMedicine)



*7. Required Response*

Please respond *only* with:

·       Compensation confirmation

·       Correct medicine delivery schedule

·       Return pickup schedule

·       CEO-signed admission letter

Any further *template emails* about wallet refunds will be treated as
*deliberate
evasion* and added to the complaint record.



*Sincerely,*

*Sanjeev Murlidhar Belagali*
Mobile: 99699 44689

--

and/or privileged material. The information contained in this e-mail is 
intended solely for the use of the individual to whom it is addressed. If 
you are not the intended recipient, you are hereby notified that any

4.    Previous wrong 500 mg strips still not taken back
5.    No refund, no replacement, no compensation
This establishes:
·       Gross negligence
·       Willful disregard of patient safety
·       Systemic failure in PharmEasy supply chain
·       Criminal negligence (Sec 338 IPC)
·       Breach of Drugs & Cosmetics Act (Sec 18(a))
·       Unfair trade practice (CPA Sec 2(9))
·       Deficiency in service (CPA Sec 2(1)(o))
·       Endangering a medically vulnerable consumer
 
3. PharmEasy’s Responses Show Continued Evasion
Your email dated 02-Sep-2025 again discussed:
·       ₹1,200 wallet refund
·       ₹995 refund
·       ₹2,000 refund request; thereafter, no response.
None of these have any relevance to the:
·       Health damage caused
·       Repeated wrong delivery
·       Criminal violations
·       Pending compensation for June, August, and now December violations
·       Non-collection of wrong medicines
·       Delay of 160+ days in grievance resolution
Your repeated template emails prove willful evasion of legal responsibility.
 
4. Legal Violations (Complete List)
A. Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940
·       Section 18(a) – Supplying incorrect dosage of a prescription drug (three times).
B. Consumer Protection Act, 2019
·       Section 2(1)(o) – Deficiency in service
·       Section 2(9)(ii) – Unfair trade practice
·       Section 14(1)(d) – Mandatory compensation for harm
C. IPC (Indian Penal Code)
·       Sec 338 – Grievous hurt by negligence
·       Sec 191 – False statements / perjury (“failed delivery” claim)
D. E-Commerce Rules, 2020
·       Rule 5(2) – Failure to ensure accurate delivery
·       Rule 5(3) – Failure to redress grievances
 
5. My Demands (FINAL & NON-NEGOTIABLE)
1. Compensation for Damages: ₹6,50,000 ((Breakdown: ₹4L health damages + ₹2L mental agony + ₹50K legal costs)
For:
·       Severe spikes in blood sugar
·       Medical risk & treatment
·       Mental agony
·       Time loss
·       Legal costs
·       160+ days of unresolved grievance
2. Immediate Delivery of Correct Medicine
·       5 strips pending from earlier orders
·       9 strips from 07-Dec-2025 order
·       Return pickup of all wrongly delivered 500 mg strips (multiple months pending)
3. CEO-Signed Written Acknowledgement of Error
As repeated drug dosage errors qualify as life-threatening negligence.
 
6. Final Legal Action (If Not Resolved Within 12 Hours)
I will be proceeding with:
A. E-Daakhil Consumer Court Filing
·       Claim amount: ₹10,00,000
·       Injunction request to restrict PharmEasy’s prescription medicine deliveries
B. Police FIR
·       Sec 338 IPC
·       Sec 27 Drugs & Cosmetics Act
C. DCGI Complaint
·       Request for investigation & license action
D. Public Disclosure
·       Media submission
·       Social media (#PharmEasyEndangersLives #PharmEasyGivesWrongMedicine)
 
7. Required Response
Please respond only with:
·       Compensation confirmation
·       Correct medicine delivery schedule
·       Return pickup schedule
·       CEO-signed admission letter
Any further template emails about wallet refunds will be treated as deliberate evasion and added to the complaint record.
 
Sincerely,
Sanjeev Murlidhar Belagali
Mobile: 99699 44689

notes.body:
*Subject:* Re: Repeated Wrong Medicine Delivery – Order
#656531285027880960-50248 & Previous Pending Issue

Dear Grievance Officer,
Greetings.

I acknowledge your email.

As requested, I will share the photographs of the items delivered for *Order
#656531285027880960-50248*, including:

   - Delivered strip images
   - PharmEasy barcode/QR sticker
   - Batch number clearly visible

However, I would also like to put on record the following for your official
investigation and internal escalation:



*1. This is a repeated dispensing error*

On *07-Dec-2025*, I ordered:

*Dianorm M OD 1000 mg – Qty: 9*

But on *08-Dec-2025 @ 16:25 hrs*, your delivery partner again delivered:

❌ *Dianorm M OD 500 mg (incorrect medicine)*

This is the *second consecutive incident*, after my earlier complaint where:

   - Wrong medicine was delivered
   - Wrong medicine was not collected back
   - Refund & compensation are still pending
   - My issue is unresolved for several weeks

These repeated incidents raise serious concerns regarding:

   - Pharmacist supervision
   - Prescription validation
   - Patient safety compliance
   - Schedule H/H1 drug handling protocols



*2. Previous wrong delivery issue still unresolved*

I again place on record that:

   - The earlier Dianorm M OD 500 mg strips (wrong medicine) images already
   shared
   ? *are still lying unused with me*
   - No pickup has happened
   - No refund or compensation has been provided
   - Your team is continuously asking only for bank details, but no final
   action

This ongoing delay is unacceptable and creates a serious *consumer safety
risk*.



*3. Request for immediate consolidated resolution*

I request that you:

*A. Arrange for compensation already mentioned in my previous email
(Rs.650,000).*

*B. Only after compensation arrange an urgent pickup of the current and
earlier wrong medicines delivered to me and replacement of the exact
correct medicine ordered.*

*C. Issue a full refund for the previous order*

*D. Provide a written explanation of corrective action taken*



*4. Please confirm the official escalation authority*

For transparency and documentation, kindly confirm:

   - The name & designation of the *Chief Grievance Officer*
   - The *Authorized Signatory* responsible for Schedule H/H1 compliance
   - The compliance officer handling incorrect medicine dispensing cases
   - The regulatory reporting protocol followed by PharmEasy

This is required for proper submission of documents to *Consumer Court*
and, if needed, to *State Drug Control Administration*.



Attached the requested photographs for your records.

Looking forward to your prompt and final resolution.

Regards,
*Sanjeev Belagali*

 9969944689

notes.body:
*Subject:* FINAL NOTICE: Repeated Wrong Medicine Delivery – Compensation
Required Within 24 Hours


Dear Grievance Officer,
CC: Compliance & Legal Team
CC: Senior Management – Axelia Solutions Pvt. Ltd. (PharmEasy)


This email serves as my *final written notice* before I proceed with legal
escalation due to repeated dispensing of *wrong prescription medicines* in
two separate orders:

   - *Order #610096008386125824-77916*
   - *Order #656531285027880960-50248*
   -

*1. PharmEasy Has Repeated the Same Error Thrice (Medical Negligence)*

Despite previous complaints, PharmEasy has again delivered:

*Dianorm M OD 500 mg instead of Dianorm M OD 1000 mg*

This is not an operational error — it is a *dangerous, repeated, and
negligent dispensing violation* that directly affects a diabetic patient.

Such repeated errors fall under:

   - *Drugs & Cosmetics Act, 1940*
   - *Consumer Protection Act, 2019*
   - *E-commerce Rules, 2020*
   - *IPC Section 336/338 (endangering life/health)*



*2. Compensation Must Be Settled First — Only Then Will Return of Wrong
Medicines Be Done*

In accordance with consumer protection rights and due to the documented
repeated negligence, I will return the wrong medicines *only after*:

*✔** Written confirmation of compensation*

*✔** Confirmation of payment date*

*✔** Refund timelines for both orders*

I will not surrender the medicines until compensation is resolved because:

   - They are *evidence of service deficiency and unsafe dispensing*
   - Prior refunds were delayed even after return
   - The dispute is *not yet resolved*

This is fully compliant with the Consumer Protection Act.



*3. My Final Demand (Non-Negotiable)*

You are required to comply with the following *within 24 hours*:

*1. Written confirmation of compensation amount*

*2. Date of transfer of compensation*

*3. Written confirmation of refunds for both orders*

*4. A single scheduled pickup after the above points are confirmed*



*4. If PharmEasy Fails to Respond Within 24 Hours*

I will initiate the following actions *without further notice*:

*A. Consumer Court (E-Daakhil)*

Claiming:

   - ₹10,00,000 compensation
   - Legal expenses
   - Medical risk exposure
   - Ban on negligent dispensing practices

*B. DCGI + State Drug Inspector Complaint*

For:

   - Wrong dosage dispensing
   - Repeated prescription medicine errors
   - Endangering patient safety
   - Possible license audit/suspension of the supplying pharmacy

*C. FIR at Local Police Station*

Under:

   - *IPC 336/338* – Act endangering life through negligence
   - *Drugs Act Section 27* – Wrong dispensing of Schedule H drugs



*5. FINAL 24-HOUR DEADLINE*

If the compensation confirmation is not received within *24 hours*, all
legal and regulatory escalations will begin.


This notice is issued *without prejudice* to my rights.


Regards,
*Sanjeev Belagali*
Mobile: 9969944689

Summary of the issues so far. 1. 594888562692067328-77026 FL1167140104 Order Placed - 20th Jun, 08:03 AM Delivered - 20th Jun, 05:00 PM This same issue happened, and the wrong item was delivered. We had credited Rs. 1322.44 to the PharmEasy wallet to place an order for the same.      2. 610096008386125824-77916 FL1170880452 Order Placed - 1st Aug, 07:12 AM Delivered - 2nd Aug, 08:11 PM  This same issue happened, and the wrong item was delivered. A refund of Rs.  995.95 was made to the Cx bank account. A new order was placed free of cost. We had credited Rs. 1200 to the PharmEasy wallet to place an order for the same. *Subject:* Non-Compliance With Resolution Obligations – Compensation
Confirmation Required Prior to Return


Dear Grievance Officer,
Axelia Solutions Pvt. Ltd. (PharmEasy)


This email is issued in continuation of my previous communications
regarding the repeated delivery of incorrect prescription medicines under
the following orders:

   - *Order #610096008386125824-77916*
   - *Order #656531285027880960-50248*

I am placing this on record for the final time before initiating statutory
proceedings.



*1. Attempted Pickup Without Settlement is a Breach of PharmEasy’s Own
Terms*

PharmEasy attempted pickup of the medicines *without providing any written
confirmation related to:*

   1. Compensation
   2. Refund timelines
   3. Resolution terms

This is *contrary to your own Terms & Conditions*, specifically:

*Clause: “In case of a dispute, the customer is entitled to seek redressal
prior to the return of disputed goods.”*

*(Paraphrased from the Returns/Refunds & Grievance Redressal sections of
PharmEasy’s policy.)*

Additionally, under the *Indian Evidence Act*, the disputed goods
remain *material
evidence* until resolution is mutually concluded.

Therefore, any pickup attempt *prior to settlement* is procedurally
inappropriate and violates your stated grievance redressal norms.



*2. Return Will Only Be Executed After Written Compensation Confirmation*

As per the *Consumer Protection Act, 2019*, a consumer is *not required to
surrender defective or disputed goods* pending settlement of a compensation
claim.

Given the nature of the error—*wrong dosage of diabetes medication
delivered twice*—the matter qualifies as:

   - *Deficiency in Service*
   - *Unfair Trade Practice*
   - *Supply of unsafe/incorrect medicines* under *Section 18(a) of the
   Drugs & Cosmetics Act*

Accordingly, I will release the medicines *only after PharmEasy provides,
in writing:*

*a) Compensation amount*

*b) Date and mode of payment*

*c) Refund timelines for both orders*

*d) Confirmation of a single combined pickup post-settlement*

This is a reasonable and legally compliant request, fully supported under
consumer law.



*3. Repeated Dispensing Errors Constitute Serious Regulatory Violations*

Your dispensing partner/pharmacy has twice supplied the *wrong strength* of
a Schedule-H diabetic medicine (Dianorm M OD 500 mg instead of 1000 mg).

This constitutes violations of:

*▪ Section 18(a) – Drugs & Cosmetics Act*

*▪ Rules governing Schedule H dispensing*

*▪ E-commerce Rules, 2020 – Failure of due diligence*

*▪ Consumer Protection Act – Sections 2(1)(o) and 2(9)*

*▪ IPC Sections 336/338 (endangering human life)*

The fact that this issue has *recurred despite prior filing* significantly
aggravates liability.



*4. PharmEasy is Required to Respond Professionally, Not Selectively*

To date, you have proceeded only with *pickup attempts*, while ignoring:

   - My request for compensation
   - My documented medical risk
   - The fact that prior refunds were delayed for weeks
   - The previous unresolved dispute for the same error

A proper resolution requires *addressing all parts of the grievance*, not
just logistics.



*5. FINAL 12-HOUR NOTICE BEFORE LEGAL & REGULATORY ACTION*

If PharmEasy fails to provide the written settlement confirmation mentioned
above within *12 hours*, I will initiate proceedings without further
communication:

*A) Consumer Court – E-Daakhil Filing*

Seeking:

   - ₹6,50,000 compensation
   - Refunds with interest
   - Penalties for repeated medical negligence
   - Directions against your dispensing partner’s licence

*B) Complaint to DCGI & State Drug Inspector*

Requesting:

   - Audit of pharmacy supplying the medicines
   - Suspension of dispensing licence for repeated wrong dosage delivery

*C) FIR Under IPC 336, 338 & Drugs Act Section 27*

*D) Public Disclosure Across Social Platforms*

Using documented evidence, invoices, delivery proof, and your responses.



*6. This Notice is Issued Without Prejudice*

I am willing to close this matter amicably *only if* PharmEasy provides the
written confirmation requested above.

Once settlement is confirmed, I will cooperate fully with the consolidated
return and refund process.

Regards,
*Sanjeev Murlidhar Belagali*
Mobile: 9969944689

notes.body:
*Subject: Without Prejudice: Acknowledgement of Partial Payment – No
Settlement Accepted*


Dear Grievance Officer,
Axelia Solutions Pvt. Ltd. (PharmEasy)


This email is to formally place on record the following:

On *15-Dec-2025*, an amount of *₹1,788.21* was credited to my ICICI Bank
account by Axelia Solutions Pvt. Ltd., *without any accompanying
communication, explanation, or settlement terms*, and *without responding
to my final legal notice dated 12-Dec-2025*.



*1. No Settlement Has Been Accepted*

Please note clearly:

   - The said amount has been *received unilaterally*
   - It was *not communicated as a full and final settlement*
   - I have *not given consent* to accept this amount in discharge of
   liability
   - The core issues of *medical negligence, repeated wrong medicine
   delivery, compensation, and regulatory violations remain unresolved*

Accordingly, this payment is treated *strictly as a partial, interim credit*,
and *not* as settlement of my claims.



*2. Silent Payment Reinforces Admission of Deficiency*

Your act of transferring funds *without replying* to a formal legal notice
constitutes:

   - Implied acknowledgment of *deficiency in service*
   - Failure to follow statutory grievance redressal obligations
   - Continued unfair trade practice by avoidance of written accountability

This conduct will be specifically relied upon in proceedings before
the *Consumer
Court and Drug Regulatory Authorities*.



*3. Outstanding Issues (Unchanged)*

For avoidance of doubt, PharmEasy has still failed to address:

   1. Compensation for repeated dispensing of wrong Schedule-H diabetic
   medicines
   2. Medical risk and mental agony caused
   3. Refund & resolution of *both affected orders*
   4. Written explanation and corrective action
   5. Regulatory non-compliance of the dispensing pharmacy



*4. Final Opportunity to Resolve Amicably*

If PharmEasy intends to resolve this matter without litigation, please
provide *within 48 hours*:

   - Written settlement terms
   - Compensation proposal
   - Refund confirmation for all disputed orders
   - Compliance and corrective-action statement

Failing which, I will proceed with statutory remedies *without further
correspondence*.



This communication is issued *without prejudice to all my legal rights and
remedies*.


Regards,
*Sanjeev Murlidhar Belagali*
Mobile: 9969944689

notes.body: Hello Neera Prasad,     Greetings from PharmEasy!     This email is with reference to the concern raised to cancel your order #656303712083673088-97855.     As per the records, your order is canceled on 10th December. We apologize for any inconvenience caused to you with your order.     Also we would like to inform you that cancellation refund of Rs.1579.72/- and Rs.43.39/- initiated and will be refunded to UPI in 5-7 working days.     We would request you to place a new order and allow us to serve you. We look forward to having an opportunity to serve you in the future.     We are marking the ticket as resolved. If you have any queries, please feel free to get back to us.     For any further assistance, please reopen this ticket or reach out to us through our support channels, in the App or website, listed in the 'Need Help' section.     Thank you for choosing PharmEasy. Have a great day ahead!     Regards,  PharmEasy
notes.body_html:
Hello Neera Prasad,

Greetings from PharmEasy!
 
This email is with reference to the concern raised to cancel your order #656303712083673088-97855.
 
As per the records, your order is canceled on 10th December. We apologize for any inconvenience caused to you with your order.

Also we would like to inform you that cancellation refund of Rs.1579.72/- and Rs.43.39/- initiated and will be refunded to UPI in 5-7 working days.
 
We would request you to place a new order and allow us to serve you. We look forward to having an opportunity to serve you in the future.
 
We are marking the ticket as resolved. If you have any queries, please feel free to get back to us.
 
For any further assistance, please reopen this ticket or reach out to us through our support channels, in the App or website, listed in the 'Need Help' section.
 
Thank you for choosing PharmEasy. Have a great day ahead!
 
Regards,
PharmEasy

helpdesk_ticket.description:
Dear Sir/Madam,
This is to formally escalate a very serious issue regarding an incorrect
Prolactin test report generated through PharmEasy, powered by Thyrocare,
which has direct implications for patient safety.
On 28 November 2025 , I underwent a serum Prolactin test booked via
PharmEasy, processed by Thyrocare, and the report showed a significantly
abnormal value. Based on this first report, there was a clear risk of my
doctor starting inappropriate treatment and further investigations on the
wrong premise. Prolactin levels are critical for diagnosing endocrine and
reproductive disorders, and falsely high or low values can lead to
misdiagnosis, unnecessary imaging, and wrong or delayed treatment.
Due to serious doubts about the plausibility of the result, the same
Prolactin test was repeated at Dr. Lal Path Labs within a short interval,
and the second report showed a markedly different value, which my doctor
considered clinically more consistent. This large discrepancy between two
tests taken close together strongly indicates an error in the first report
(PharmEasy/Thyrocare). Inaccurate laboratory reports are not a minor
service issue; they can directly cause wrong diagnosis, unnecessary
medicines, avoidable procedures, psychological stress, and long‑term health
harm to patients.
Given the above, I demand the following:
1 A written root‑cause analysis clarifying how such an incorrect Prolactin
report was generated (including checks on sample handling, labeling, assay
calibration, quality control, and report validation steps).
2 A written confirmation on what corrective and preventive actions (CAPA)
will be implemented so that such serious laboratory errors do not recur.
3 Immediate correction/annotation of my report in your system, clearly
marking the earlier Prolactin value as “suspect/erroneous” so that no
clinician relies on it in future.
4 A formal written apology acknowledging the seriousness of this incident
and its potential impact on my treatment.
5 Details of your escalation hierarchy and regulatory/quality
certifications under which this lab operates, including how I can approach
the next level if this issue is not addressed satisfactorily.
In medical diagnostics, accuracy and reliability of reports are
non‑negotiable. A patient and treating doctor rely entirely on your reports
to make critical treatment decisions. Any lapse here is a serious breach of
professional responsibility and patient trust and can amount to negligence
if it leads to harm.
Kindly treat this matter as urgent and respond in writing within 2 working
days from receipt of this email/letter. If a satisfactory response is not
received, I will be constrained to place this matter before appropriate
consumer and regulatory forums.
Regards,
KRISHNA LAKHOTIA
9641022830

--

helpdesk_ticket.subject: Urgent Escalation – Incorrect Prolactin Test Report Leading to Risk of Wrong Treatment
helpdesk_ticket.description_html:
Dear Sir/Madam,
This is to formally escalate a very serious issue regarding an incorrect Prolactin test report generated through PharmEasy, powered by Thyrocare, which has direct implications for patient safety.
On 28 November 2025 , I underwent a serum Prolactin test booked via PharmEasy, processed by Thyrocare, and the report showed a significantly abnormal value. Based on this first report, there was a clear risk of my doctor starting inappropriate treatment and further investigations on the wrong premise. Prolactin levels are critical for diagnosing endocrine and reproductive disorders, and falsely high or low values can lead to misdiagnosis, unnecessary imaging, and wrong or delayed treatment. 
Due to serious doubts about the plausibility of the result, the same Prolactin test was repeated at Dr. Lal Path Labs within a short interval, and the second report showed a markedly different value, which my doctor considered clinically more consistent. This large discrepancy between two tests taken close together strongly indicates an error in the first report (PharmEasy/Thyrocare). Inaccurate laboratory reports are not a minor service issue; they can directly cause wrong diagnosis, unnecessary medicines, avoidable procedures, psychological stress, and long‑term health harm to patients.
Given the above, I demand the following:
1 A written root‑cause analysis clarifying how such an incorrect Prolactin report was generated (including checks on sample handling, labeling, assay calibration, quality control, and report validation steps).
2 A written confirmation on what corrective and preventive actions (CAPA) will be implemented so that such serious laboratory errors do not recur.
3 Immediate correction/annotation of my report in your system, clearly marking the earlier Prolactin value as “suspect/erroneous” so that no clinician relies on it in future. 
4 A formal written apology acknowledging the seriousness of this incident and its potential impact on my treatment.
5 Details of your escalation hierarchy and regulatory/quality certifications under which this lab operates, including how I can approach the next level if this issue is not addressed satisfactorily.
In medical diagnostics, accuracy and reliability of reports are non‑negotiable. A patient and treating doctor rely entirely on your reports to make critical treatment decisions. Any lapse here is a serious breach of professional responsibility and patient trust and can amount to negligence if it leads to harm.
Kindly treat this matter as urgent and respond in writing within 2 working days from receipt of this email/letter. If a satisfactory response is not received, I will be constrained to place this matter before appropriate consumer and regulatory forums.

KRISHNA LAKHOTIA

notes.body:
Hi KRISHNA LAKHOTIA,     Greetings from Pharmeasy!     As discussed over the call, the patient woke up at 7:00 AM and provided the sample between 7:15–7:30 AM at the PharmEasy lab. At Lal Path Lab, the patient gave the sample at 11:00 AM after waking up between 7:00–7:30 AM.  We would like to inform you that Prolactin levels fluctuate throughout the day. It is recommended to perform the Prolactin test early in the morning, ideally 3–4 hours after waking up. This guideline is also mentioned in the report as well as on the PharmEasy website.     Best Regards,     Yuvraj Korpe,  Diagnostics Quality Team   
                           
                            On
                            Mon, 8 Dec at  5:20 PM
                            ,  PharmEasy
notes.body_html:
Hi KRISHNA LAKHOTIA,

Greetings from Pharmeasy!

As discussed over the call, the patient woke up at 7:00 AM and provided the sample between 7:15–7:30 AM at the PharmEasy lab. At Lal Path Lab, the patient gave the sample at 11:00 AM after waking up between 7:00–7:30 AM.

We would like to inform you that Prolactin levels fluctuate throughout the day. It is recommended to perform the Prolactin test early in the morning, ideally 3–4 hours after waking up. This guideline is also mentioned in the report as well as on the PharmEasy website.
